Title: TOKAMAK FUSION CORE EXPERIMENT MAINTENANCE STUDY.
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Snyder Alan M., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Watts K.D., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: The recently completed Tokamak Fusion Core Experiment (TFCX) design project investigated potential 'next generation' tokamak concepts. An important early development of the design was the incorporation of remote maintainability. Early coordination and incorporation of maintenance aspects to the design of the device and facilities will ensure that the machine can ultimately be maintained and repaired efficiently and cost effectively. A rigorously formatted engineering trade study was performed to determine the preferred configuration for the TFCX reactor based primarily on maintenance requirements. The study indicates a preferred design with an external vacuum vessel and torodial field coils that can be removed by simple radial motion. The trade study is presented and the preferred TFCX configuration is described.
Index Keywords: Tokamak devices; REMOTE MAINTENANCE; TFCX; TOKAMAK FUSION CORE EXPERIMENT; NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR

Authors: Raimondi T.; Huguet M.; Sonnerup L.
Title: MECHANICAL STRUCTURE OF THE JOINT EUROPEAN TORUS (JET), AND PROVISIONS FOR ASSEMBLY AND REMOTE HANDLING.
Abstract: The JET mechanical structure is designed to resist, with suitable stiffness, the large azimuthal forces acting on the 32 toroidal field coils. It consists of 8 identical sectors each of which, together with 4 toroidal coils and one octant of vacuum vessel, can be replaced if defective by means of sliding equipment. It must also be possible to perform this operation remotely. The basic remote handling equipment consists of general purpose telemanipulators with TV systems, positioned either outside or inside the machine. Some preliminary feasibility tests have been carried out.
Index Keywords: STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Stresses; Plasma devices
Publisher: IEEE Nucl and Plasma Sci Soc (IEEE Publ n 75CH1097-5-NPS)

Authors: Berger J.D.; Kelly V.P.; Yount J.A.
Title: IN-VESSEL MAINTENANCE CONCEPTS FOR TOKAMAK FUSION REACTORS.
Abstract: Concepts for rail-mounted and guided in-vessel handling machines (IVM) for remote maintenance inside tokamak fusion reactors are described. The IVM designs are based on concepts for tethered remotely operated vehicles and feature the use of multiple manipulator arms for remote handling and remote-controlled TV cameras for remote viewing. The concepts include IVMs for both single or dual rail systems located in the top or bottom of the reactor vessel.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS - Fusion; Remote control; IN-VESSEL HANDLING MACHINES; Tokamak devices

Authors: Rappe G.H.; Hohbach A.C.; Jensen R.A.
Title: CHALLENGES OF TOKAMAK FUSION TEST REACTOR (TFTR) MAINTENANCE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
Abstract: Procedures and equipment are being developed to provide a viable maintenance system which satisfy the operational objectives of TFTR. Some of the more difficult and challenging areas include the neutral beam duct - vacuum vessel joint, poloidal field coils and the inner support structure. Later fusion machines (e. g. , prototype reactors) will have different reliability and maintainability requirements. Some of these considerations are addressed.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR; Tokamak devices

Authors: Spampinato P.T.; Sardella C.; Shannon T.E.
Title: DESIGN IMPROVEMENTS TO SIMPLIFY THE REMOTE MAINTENANCE OF TOKAMAKS.
Abstract: By the nature of its plasma confinement concept, the tokamak is a difficult device to maintain; maintainability problems are compounded by the need to perform all operations remotely. Modifications to the Oak Ridge National Laboratory baseline, the next step (TNS), which led to significant improvements in device maintainability, are discussed. These modifications are: a reduction in the number of toroidal field coils used and an increase in coil size, a rearrangement of poloidal field coils to preclude the need for coil dismantling during a torus sector replacement, and use of a secondary vacuum enclosure. Various types of secondary enclosures are discussed and the rationale for selecting a vacuum building approach is given.
Index Keywords: REMOTE MAINTENANCE; Tokamak devices

Authors: Masson L.S.; Welland H.J.
Title: TOKAMAK FUSION CORE EXPERIMENT (TFCX) SPECIAL-PURPOSE REMOTE MAINTENANCE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Masson L.S., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA; Welland H.J., EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID,, USA, EG&G Idaho Inc, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: A key element in the preconceptual design of the Tokamak Fusion Core Experiment (TFCX) was the development of design concepts for special-purpose remote maintenance systems. Included were systems for shield sector replacement, vacuum vessel sector and toroidal field coil replacement, limiter blade replacement, protective tile replacement, and general-purpose maintenance. This paper addresses these systems as they apply to the copper toroidal field (TF) coil version of the TFCX.
Index Keywords: TOKAMAK DEVICES - Maintenance; REACTOR SHIELDING; REMOTE MAINTENANCE SYSTEMS; TFCX; TOKAMAK FUSION CORE EXPERIMENT; NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR

Authors: Vertut J.; Rouyer J.L.; Clement G.
Title: TELETRANS CONCEPT FOR REMOTE MAINTENANCE OF TOKAMAK REACTORS.
Affiliations: CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr, CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr
Authors with affiliations: Vertut J., CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr, CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr; Rouyer J.L., CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr, CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr; Clement G., CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr, CEA, Fontenay-aux-Roses, Fr
Abstract: Teletrans is a concept that combines and optimizes teleoperation remote contained transfer. Application to Tokamaks enables the use of a vacuum vessel in high integrity contained transfer enclosures. They carry their inner teleoperation system and are connected by double door technique either to torus or shielded contained hot cells.
Index Keywords: MATERIALS HANDLING - Manipulators; NUCLEAR REACTORS, FUSION - Radiation Protection; SYSTEMS ENGINEERING; TRITIUM; TELEOPERATION; TELETRANS CONCEPT; TOKAMAK DEVICES

Authors: Dean J.; Raimondi T.
Title: CONCEPTS AND STATUS OF REMOTE HANDLING IN JET.
Affiliations: JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Dean J., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl; Raimondi T., JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl, JET Joint Undertaking, Abingdon, Engl
Abstract: The design of JET is such that the main sub-assemblies are replaceable remotely by means of servo-manipulators in combination with the crane bridge. The special features to facilitate remote handling are described in the JET Remote Handling Manual. Servo-manipulators are floor mounted. Their transporters are 'stand alone' systems, which only require the use of the crane to carry and position them into broad working areas. In this way the mobility and availability of the crane are maximised. The installation of large sub-assemblies such as the octants and the PF coils has shown that the concepts adopted can be viable for Remote Handling.
Index Keywords: ROBOTS, INDUSTRIAL - Manipulators; ABSTRACT ONLY; JET REMOTE HANDLING MANUAL; SERVO-MANIPULATORS; TV REMOTE CONTROL INSPECTION; MATERIALS HANDLING

Authors: Bolta C.C.; Stevens H.C.
Title: REMOTE MAINTENANCE CONSIDERATIONS FOR THE TOKAMAK EXPERIMENTAL POWER REACTOR.
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Abstract: The earliest versions of tokamak reactors capable of producing power for electrical generation will introduce the first full measure of remote maintenance conditions required for future machines. A description of the proposed remote maintenance techniques specifically related to design problems and potential solutions for the Experimental Power Reactor is presented. Coverage of important requirements such as replacement and repair of first-wall components, repair of coolant and vacuum lines, and tritium handling problems are included.
Index Keywords: Tokamak devices; REMOTE MAINTENANCE; NUCLEAR REACTORS, THERMONUCLEAR

Authors: Gomay Yoshio; Hamajima Takataro; Honda Tsutomu; Kitamura Kazunori; Manukata Tadashi; Uchida Takao; Yamaguchi Mitsugi; Yamato Harumi
Author full names: Gomay, Yoshio (6603913276); Hamajima, Takataro (7005685026); Honda, Tsutomu (7402895073); Kitamura, Kazunori (7403116924); Manukata, Tadashi (6504087067); Uchida, Takao (57097214100); Yamaguchi, Mitsugi (7404823946); Yamato, Harumi (23040605000)
Title: MAINTENANCE METHOD FOR TOKAMAK FUSION REACTORS WITH DOWNWARD ACCESS TO TORUS INBOARD STRUCTURES.
Source title: Journal of Nuclear Science and Technology
Abstract: A concept of tokamak fusion reactor maintenance is presented. Reactor structures and maintenance machines are arranged so that the component inside a shielding structure can be replaced through the hatches located on the upper side of the torus shielding structure. The objective of the study is to conceive a realistic method of maintenance for tokamak reactors, in particular for their inboard structures.
Index Keywords: TOKAMAK DEVICES - Maintenance; NUCLEAR REACTORS
